Key Arguments: The Bill represents a significant overreach by the government.
It is inconsistent with fundamental freedoms of speech and communication under international human rights instruments.
The Bill grants too much power to unelected bureaucrats without transparency or accountability.
The definition of 'harm' is vague and could be weaponized to suppress legitimate speech.
There is no requirement for digital service providers to be held liable for excessive policing of speech.
Excluding government-authorized content from the regime is hypocritical and creates an asymmetry in speech regulation.
The Bill gives ACMA excessive powers that breach privacy.
There is insufficient accountability and oversight for misuse of censorship powers.
Provisions for freedom of expression are tokenistic and do not meet international law standards.
Penalties for non-compliance are excessive and could chill free speech.
Notable Quotes: The Bill is inconsistent with fundamental freedoms of speech and communication under international human rights instruments.
The Bill puts too much power in the hands of unelected bureaucrats to silence speech in the public square without transparency or accountability.

The severity of the penalties for failing to comply with the misinformation codes and standards and for failing to provide evidence requested by ACMA is excessive and will provide a ‘chilling effect’ on free speech.
